metadata.title: A density functional theory based elementary reaction mechanism for early steps of Fischer-Tropsch synthesis over cobalt catalyst. 2. Microkinetic modeling of liquid-phase vs. gaseous-phase process

Fig. 1 TS configurations of elementary reaction CH3CO**+H*↔CH3CHO**+*, under gaseous- (a) and liquid-phase (b) FTS. The carbon, oxygen, cobalt, and hydrogen atoms are shown by grey, red, blue, and white colors, respectively. The provided values represent the center-to-center distances between the two atoms at the ends of the arrows. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Surface reaction pathways for CO conversion to the main products in gaseous-phase FTS at 493K and 25bar. The numbers on the arrows represent the reactions’ net rate relative to the slowest step (CO* unassisted dissociation). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Surface reaction pathways for CO conversion to the main FTS products in the presence of liquid hexane at 493K and 25bar. The numbers on the arrows represent the reactions’ net rate relative to the slowest step (CO* unassisted dissociation). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Energy profile of C2-oxygenated formation in the considered FTS mechanism under different phase conditions. The red and blue profiles correspond to the gaseous-phase and liquid-phase conditions, respectively. TS1-4 correspond to the elementary reactions 19-22 in Table 1 and the provided values on the energy surface represent the heights of the associated barriers. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Free energy profile of C2-oxygenated formation in the considered FTS mechanism under different phase conditions. The red and blue profiles represent variations in the gaseous- and liquid-phase processes, respectively. Table 3 Reaction Gaseous-phase Liquid-phase CO*↔CO+* 60.1 52.0 2H*↔H2 +2* 38.7 25.9 H2O*↔H2O+* 14.4 -0.005 CO2**↔CO2 +2* -12.1 -25.4 CH3*+H*↔CH4 +2* -0.8 -11.4 CH3CH2*+H*↔C2H6 +2* -29.0 -39.5 CH2CH2**↔C2H4 +2* 27.9 16.5 Research paper A density functional theory based elementary reaction mechanism for early steps of Fischer-Tropsch synthesis over cobalt catalyst. 2. Microkinetic modeling of liquid-phase vs. gaseous-phase process Alireza Asiaee Kenneth M. Benjamin ⁎ Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, South Dakota School of Mines and Technology, 501 E. Saint Joseph St., Rapid City, SD 57701, USA Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering South Dakota School of Mines and Technology 501 E. St. Saint Joseph St. Rapid City SD 57701 USA ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The process of Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) is conducted commercially under both gaseous- and liquid-phase conditions. For decades, numerous studies have been performed to better understand this heterogeneous catalytic process, where some of them have tried to compare the reaction rates and product distributions of FTS under different phase conditions. In spite of several provided models, the actual reaction mechanisms and kinetics of important elementary steps at each phase condition are still under investigation, especially in the liquid-phase. In this work, we have utilized the generalized-gradient approximation method of density functional theory (DFT-GGA) to estimate the rate parameters of elementary reactions in liquid-phase FTS on a flat Co(0001) catalyst surface. In this regard, using the continuum-based conductor-like screening model (COSMO) for the liquid solvent environment, the activation energies and rate constants of individual reactions, suggested in an existing microkinetic model, have been calculated in the presence of n-hexane solvent at T =493K and P =25bar. The preferred reaction pathway has been discussed and the quantitative results have been compared to that of the gaseous-phase in order to find the impact of liquid solvent, as well as differences in the probable surface reactions under each phase condition. It has been found that while the carbide mechanism is the dominant mechanism of chain growth under both phase conditions, the presence of the liquid solvent enhanced the CO insertion sub-mechanism of chain growth, which can describe some of the experimental observations in FTS studies. Keywords Fischer-Tropsch synthesis DFT Microkinetic modeling Liquid-phase solvent effect 1 Introduction Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) is considered an economic way toward conversion of natural gas to more valuable hydrocarbon products [1]. Industrially, catalytic FTS processes are conducted under two different conditions of gaseous-phase in a fixed- or fluidized-bed reactor and liquid-phase in a slurry bubble column reactor. While the fixed-bed reactor is normally used to produce diesel fuel, the fluidized-bed reactor produces gasoline fraction along with high yield of methane. Both types of gaseous-phase reactors suffer from continual catalyst deactivation. On the other hand, liquid-phase FTS in a slurry bubble column reactor provides less methane production and catalyst deactivation. Unfavorably, due to low concentration of the reactants and larger diffusion barriers, the overall reaction rates in the liquid-phase are significantly slower than those in the gaseous-phase [2]. Another classification divides FTS in two categories of high-temperature processes, operating within the range of 300–350°C, and low-temperature processes with a temperature range of 200–240°C. Generally, the high-temperature FTS processes operate under gaseous-phase conditions. However, the low-temperature process can be conducted under gaseous- or liquid-phase reaction conditions [3]. Among all suggested transition metal catalysts with enough activity for FTS, only the iron- and cobalt-based catalysts have the desired product distribution with affordable preparation cost for commercial production. While the iron-based catalysts can be used in both temperature ranges, the cobalt-based ones are only applicable in low-temperature FTS [4]. For decades, the product distribution of FTS has been the subject of numerous investigations [3,5–9], where some studies have tried to compare the product distribution of gaseous- and liquid-phase FTS processes under similar reaction conditions [1,2,10,11]. Based on a summary and comparison of experimental observations from the literature, CO conversion and selectivities of methane and other light alkanes (C2-C4) are higher in the gaseous-phase FTS than in liquid-phase operation. On the other hand, using the liquid solvent results in more production of mid-range hydrocarbons (C5-C11), while no particular comparison has been reported for production rates of heavy fractions (C12+) and olefins [1,3,12]. Logically, because of low diffusivity in the liquid solvent, the overall reaction rates and consequently the CO conversion in the liquid-phase would be smaller than those of gaseous-phase FTS. On the other hand, in addition to preventing catalyst deactivation [1,2], the liquid-phase FTS provides several advantageous features, such as better thermal distribution and a selective condition for dissolving of products. The improved temperature control in the slurry bubble column reactor has been considered as the main reason for less production of methane [2]. Moreover, it has been discussed that the liquid-phase medium tends to dissolve the mid-range hydrocarbon products more than the light ones, resulting in less production of undesired products [3]. However, it appears that a fundamental investigation of the effect of liquid solvents on the elementary surface reaction kinetics and pathways has been neglected in the accomplished theoretical and experimental studies to date. Generally, a better understanding of a reactive process can be achieved by studying the elementary reaction pathways. During the past two decades, several microkinetic models have been suggested for FTS [12–17]. However, the majority of the provided models were established in order to predict the gaseous-phase FTS reaction paths. In an individual study, Lozano-Blanco et al. have tried to extend their model for simulation of liquid-phase FTS in a slurry-bubble column reactor [18]. In light of the recent advances in quantum mechanics calculations and their accuracy to predict experimental catalytic results [19], several studies have used density functional theory (DFT) approaches to model the surface reactions as well as adsorption and desorption steps in the FTS reaction mechanism [16,20–23]. Despite all of the previous investigations and findings, due to the high computational cost of quantum calculations, few studies have tried to characterize and quantify the effect of liquid solvent on surface reactions in a heterogeneous catalytic process, particularly in FTS. One of the suggested approaches for considering liquid solvent effects in quantum calculations is applying the continuum-based conductor-like screening model (COSMO), which evaluates the dielectric screening effect of the solvent. In this technique, provided by Klamt and Schüürmann [24], the liquid solvent is modeled as a homogeneous medium where the solute molecule is placed in a cavity within the dielectric continuum of permittivity, representing the solvent. Later, the COSMO theory was implemented into the DFT program DMol, where the modeling results for solvation energies showed a promising agreement with experimental values [25]. In 2009, Zuo et al. applied a COSMO-based model in order to compare the CO adsorption energies upon copper-based catalyst under two different conditions of gaseous- and liquid-phase solvent [26], where their results showed significant influence of solvent phase condition on the energy of adsorption. As a continuum-based model, COSMO calculations are much less computationally expensive than an explicit atomistic approach [such as quantum molecular dynamics or hybrid quantum and molecular mechanical (QM/MM) treatments] to modeling the solvent environment. Assuming that the surface reactions and intermediate species would be identical under different phase conditions [18], the confirmed reaction mechanism in the preceding study is considered here [27]. This approach assumes the liquid solvent only contributes physically – i.e. through solvation – and not chemically to the FTS reaction network, meaning that the liquid solvent does not create otherwise new reaction pathways on the catalyst surface. In a FTS study by Marvast et al., the authors modeled the overall conversion reactions by fitting the rate parameters to experimental data [28]. In their model, they combined all the hydrocarbon products beyond the light fractions (C5 +) into a pseudo component of C6.05H12.36. Hence, in the current study, all the elementary reactions are modeled using the DFT program DMol, where the liquid-phase solvent is considered by the pseudo component of n-hexane, via applying the COSMO model. (It is assumed that solvation with hexane represents solvation with any large hydrocarbon molecule environment produced by FTS.) Through comparison of reaction barriers and rate constant parameters with those of gaseous-phase, the effect of liquid solvent on FTS reaction pathways over cobalt catalyst is probed from both energetic and kinetic aspects. 2 Computational method Similar to the preceding paper [27], the flat Co(0001) surface in the modeled unit cell contained 4 layers of p(3×3) cobalt atoms, representing a surface coverage of 1/9 monolayer (ML) for the adsorbed species occupying a single active site. The thickness of vacuum slab above the catalyst surface was set to 10Å and the unit cell boundaries were periodic in all the Cartesian directions. During all calculations, the Co atoms in the bottom two layers of the catalyst slab were fixed at their initial positions (with the minimum level of energy), while the two top layers were allowed to relax. All DFT calculations were performed with the DMol3 program of BIOVIA Materials Studio [29] using the generalized-gradient approximation of Perdew and Wang (GGA-PW) [30]. Due to the ferromagnetic nature of cobalt, calculations included spin polarization. In order to reduce the computational expense, the core electrons were replaced by a single effective potential via DFT semi-core pseudopotentials (DSPP). The optimized structures of reactants and products with the minimum energy levels were found by considering the maximum energy tolerance of 1.0×10−5 Ha. While the tolerance for self-consistent field (SCF) convergence was set to be less than 1.0×10−6 Ha, the calculated maximum displacement of atoms and force deviation were less than 5.0×10−3 Å and 2.0×10−3 Ha/Å, respectively. The transition state (TS) for each reaction and its relative energy level were found using the LST/QST method [31] with the convergence criteria of 2.0×10−3 Ha/Å and 1.0×10−6 Ha for root mean square (RMS) deviations of force and SCF tolerance, respectively. However, due to the sensitivity of these calculations, not all the TS search calculations could meet the above convergence criteria. Therefore, for some of the reactions, a set of 1.0×10−2 Ha/Å and 1.0×10−5 Ha convergence values were considered for the root mean square (RMS) deviation and the SCF tolerance, respectively. To estimate the pre-exponential factor of rate constants using the calculated vibrational frequencies and moments of inertia, the geometry refining procedure and TS search calculations were followed by frequency calculations. By applying Monkhorst-Pack grids [32], the density of k-points was kept below 0.05Å−1 through all simulation runs. As mentioned earlier, DMol calculations with the COSMO model were applied to probe the liquid-phase solvent effect. Considering n-hexane (as a pseudo-component) instead of all the hydrocarbons present in the industrial liquid-phase FTS, the dielectric value of hexane at the implemented operating condition was required for COSMO calculations. Mopsik had experimentally measured the dielectric values of hexane in the temperature range of −50 to 25°C and pressures up to 2000atm [33]. In another study by Straty and Goodwin, measurements at saturated liquid conditions showed that the methane dielectric values have a linear functionality with temperature up to near-critical conditions [34]. Therefore, by assuming linear variations with respect to both temperature and pressure, the dielectric value of n-hexane was estimated as 1.594 at the considered operating conditions of 220°C (493K) and 25bar. This temperature and pressure were selected to be as close as possible to the suggested optimum conditions for liquid-phase FTS [35], which are also valid in the conventional process of low-temperature FTS operating under gaseous-phase condition [3,36]. Lastly, using ANSYS CHEMKIN-PRO (mechanistic modeling software) [37], the complete elementary reaction model (reactions and associated parameters) was applied in a tubular reactor with the catalyst on the annular surface area in order to compare the rates and product distribution of gaseous- and liquid-phase FTS. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Estimation of rate constant parameters in liquid-phase FTS Defining the rate constant of each elementary reaction (k) by the following equation (1), k = A o exp ( − E a R T ) the activation energy (Ea ) and pre-exponential factor (Ao ) were estimated from TS search calculations and measured vibrational frequencies of geometry optimized structures, respectively. In Eq. (1), R is the universal gas constant and T stands for temperature which was 493K in this study. As it was mentioned in the previous section, the liquid solvent effects were considered in all calculations by applying the COSMO model for all reactions. Despite the difference in the phase conditions, the calculated favorable sites for each adsorbed intermediate species in the considered mechanism under liquid phase conditions were found to be the same as those in the gaseous-phase [27], resulting in similar structures and relative energies. However, the structures of the TS for some of elementary reactions possessed slightly different configurations. The TS configurations for the elementary surface reaction of CH3CO**+H*↔CH3CHO**+* (a * represents an active site upon catalyst surface) under different phase conditions are shown in Fig. 1 . In the reaction under gaseous-phase conditions, the carbon and oxygen atoms in the carbonyl group of the TS structure were occupying close to atop positions, while the favorable spots of corresponding atoms in the liquid-phase conditions were switched to bridge positions. As illustrated in the figure, the different rearrangement of the atoms due to presence of liquid solvent also altered the CO bond length. Therefore, in some cases, introducing the liquid solvent resulted in significant deviations in activation energies compared to those under gaseous-phase conditions. The calculated rate constant parameters in liquid-phase FTS are provided in Table 1 . It was observed that where the energy barrier of a reaction, Ea , had close values in both gaseous- and liquid-phase conditions (normally with less than 1kJ/mol differences), the calculated frequencies also provided similar Ao factors for both phases. Regarding with calculation of Ao factors for adsorption/desorption steps, the same approach as in the preceding study was used [27]. Although, in order to calculate the equilibrium constants of adsorption reactions (KC,ads ) using the following equation (2), K C , a d s = k a d s k d e s = exp ( − Δ G a d s R T ) where ΔGads is the change in the Gibbs energy during the adsorption process and kads and kdes stand for the rate constants of adsorption and desorption reactions, respectively, an adjustment was required to reflect the liquid-phase conditions. In a theoretical study of CO chemisorption on cobalt catalyst in the presence of different gaseous and supercritical solvents, Asiaee and Benjamin discussed that the observed variation in free energy of adsorption was largely dominated by the mixing free energy of adsorbate in the bulk solvent [38]. Hence, in this study the Gibbs energy of adsorption in the liquid-phase process (ΔGads,liquid ) was calculated using the following equation. (3), ΔGads,liquid = ΔGads,gas − ΔGmix where ΔGads,gas is the free energy of adsorption under gaseous-phase conditions, where its estimation method was described in the preceding study [27]. The correction term of ΔGmix in Eq. (3) is the mixing free energy of adsorbate in liquid hexane at 493K and 25bar and it was calculated using the Peng-Robinson equation of state [39] for different molecular adsorbate species existing in the considered mechanism at dilute conditions. In addition to providing a better condition for isolating individual effects of solvent on kinetics and pathways, dilute concentrations of adsorbate species have been considered in order to eliminate the dependency of ΔGmix on composition. 3.2 Reaction mechanism in liquid-phase vs. gaseous-phase In order to elucidate the influence of liquid solvent, the rate constants of individual elementary steps in the considered micro-mechanism were calculated and compared with those of gaseous-phase FTS. These estimated values are provided side by side in Table 2 . As it is shown in this table, unless the rate constant is corresponding with a desorption reaction, most of the rest of values are almost in the same order of magnitude under both phase conditions. However, for some of the elementary steps, especially the ones including relatively larger oxygenates (reactions 20–22 in Table 2), reaction rate constants deviated by up to an order of magnitude. To better highlight the scale of the liquid solvent effect on the kinetics and thermodynamics of the desorption process, a comparison of the free energy change associated with the desorption reactions (ΔGdes ) is provided in Table 3 . As expected, due to enhanced solubility of dilute small molecules in liquid hexane, desorption of gas species was increased in the bulk liquid-phase, compared to that of the gaseous-phase FTS. Regardless of the sign, all the calculated ΔGdes in liquid-phase conditions have lower values, meaning that the desorption process became thermodynamically more favorable in the presence of liquid solvent. Despite the fact that desorption is an endothermic process (except ethane adsorption which is associated with a bond cleavage), the value of ΔGdes can be either positive or negative. The negative values of ΔGads for CO and H2 adsorption (equivalent to ΔGdes > 0 in reverse direction, as shown in Table 3), in addition to the negative ΔGdes for desorption of CO2, methane, and ethane mean that these reactions are spontaneous, in favor of more reactant conversion to products. However, unspontaneous desorption of water and ethylene in the gaseous-phase conditions is unfavorable during the FTS process. From one viewpoint, altering the reaction condition to liquid phase may be undesired for CO and H2 adsorption, which can be consider as another reason for the slower rate of reactant conversion in liquid-phase FTS, besides the low diffusivity in the liquid solvent. On the other hand, enhanced solubility of products in the liquid hexane would reduce the concentration of intermediates on the catalyst surface and accelerate the surface reactions. Additionally, the positive liquid solvent influence is more effective for desorption of water, where the unspontaneous process in the gaseous-phase turned to a spontaneous one in the liquid-phase FTS. As the next step, to have a better understanding of the FTS mechanism under different phase conditions, the FTS process was modeled in ANSYS CHEMKIN-PRO using the estimated rate parameters in both gaseous- and liquid-phase. The same operating conditions of T =493K and P =25bar were applied, where similar dilute concentration of CO and excess H2 (H2/CO=10) were considered in the feed to both systems, to eliminate the effect of concentration on reaction rate. CHEMKIN uses rate laws of the fluid phase in terms of species concentration in the ideal gas conditions. Therefore, by introducing similar reactant concentrations, there are no inherent reaction (concentration) driving force differences between the two cases modeled here, and any differences in the outcomes are due exclusively to the kinetics, as effected by the solvent phase (gas vs. liquid). The modeled reaction pathways of FTS and the most likely generated intermediate species (containing carbon atoms) during formation of FTS main products from CO, under gaseous-phase and in presence of liquid solvent, are shown in Figs. 2 and 3 , respectively. It should be noted that the rate values for those reactions (from Table 2) that contain carbon atoms and are not shown in these schemes were 10-20 orders of magnitude smaller than that of the slowest step (CO*+*↔C*+O*) in the modeled pathways shown. In general, under both phase conditions, the main path toward the production of hydrocarbons was through surface reaction series of CO*→CHO**→CH*→CH2*→CH3*, where in termination steps methane was generated by hydrogenation of CH3* intermediate and larger hydrocarbons (C2 products) were produced through binding of CH2* and CH3* species. This reaction path, known as the carbide mechanism, has been suggested in many other studies as the main mechanism for the chain growth in the process of FTS [16,17,40,41]. Unlike some of the previous DFT studies which suggested CO insertion as the dominant mechanism of chain growth based on energy profiles [23], as it is shown in Fig. 2, the results of the current study were in favor of the carbide mechanism, in agreement with several experimental observations [42]. However, due to the discussed enhancement in the rate constants of reactions which generate C2-oxygenates (Table 2), beside the main mechanism of chain growth, a secondary reaction pathway (CO insertion mechanism) appeared to be enhanced in the liquid-phase condition (Fig. 3), which led to more production of CH3CH2* intermediate. Although the net rates in the CO insertion pathway were much (about 5 orders of magnitude) slower than the carbide mechanism, this additional side-path (with nearly 10+ order of magnitude accelerated rates compared to gaseous-phase conditions) can be considered as a good explanation for the decreased rate of methane formation observed in liquid-phase FTS, experimentally. While the reaction rate values presented in Fig. 2 and Fig. 3 were calculated at similar residence time under both phase conditions, we would like to mention that the relative values of the rates remained almost constant along the reactors through the whole modeled processes for both phases. The mentioned rate enhancement in the insertion mechanism of CO*+ CH3*→CH3CO**→CH3CHO**→CH3CH2O**→CH3CH2* in the presence of liquid solvent can be discussed using the reaction’s energy barriers and free energy changes (Figs. 4 and 5 , respectively). The free energy changes in Fig. 5 were calculated using the estimated rate constants, by applying them in Eq. (2) for the corresponding surface reaction. While the production of CH3CO** intermediate from CO* and CH3* has similar rate constants and activation energies in both phases (Tables 1 and 2), the liquid solvent not only lowered the barriers of the subsequent steps (TS2 and TS3 in Fig. 4), but also it provided a condition that made formation of CH3CHO** and CH3CH2O** thermodynamically more favorable by lowering the relative free energy levels as shown in Fig. 5. Based on the potential energies in Fig. 4, despite the slight increase in the barrier TS4 (2.9kJ/mol, which reflects the changes in energies for both the CH3CH2O** and TS4 structures under each phase condition) in the liquid-phase compared to that of gaseous phase, by reducing the magnitudes of the two subsequent activation energies (especially TS3 where there is no barrier for hydrogenation of CH3CHO** to CH3CH2O**), liquid solvent made this alternative pathway relatively more probable compared with the main mechanism of chain growth (discussed above) and resulted in increased generation of C2 products. A similar analysis can be established for the variations in the free energy profile (Fig. 5), where the reduction in the free energy levels of CH3CHO** and CH3CH2O** intermediates (1.4 and 3.3kJ/mol, respectively), due to presence of liquid solvent, were thermodynamically more effective than the slight 0.8kJ/mol increase of free energy level for the CH3CH2* species. Using CHEMKIN, the estimated parameters were applied toward calculating the rates of reactant disappearance and product generation under both phase conditions. Through modeling, the results showed negligible amounts of methane and ethylene production and the majority of reacted carbon monoxide converted to ethane and carbon dioxide. This disagreement with the expected product distribution based on the experimental results (e.g. significant methane selectivity) may be due to several reasons, which relate to the calculated rate parameters. Unfortunately, there is no direct experimental method for evaluating the rate constants of individual surface reactions in order to be compared with the computed ones. However, several experimental techniques, such as thermal desorption measurement (TPD) or Auger and sp measurements, were established to calculate the energy variation during adsorption processes. In this regard, despite the good agreement with current literature DFT values [27] (CO adsorption heats were calculated as −182.4kJ/mol [27] and −187.4kJ/mol in the gaseous- and liquid-phase conditions here, respectively), Bridge et al. and Papp reported the adsorption heat of CO on Co(0001) as −103kJ/mol and −128kJ/mol at low surface coverages (<1/3 ML), respectively [43,44]. Some studies have discussed that this over-bonding evaluation error for the CO/Co system is due to energy level misplacement of the CO* unfilled 2π* orbital in DFT calculations [45,46]. Therefore, considering the Sabatier principle through construction of the volcano plot, which describes the optimum condition regarding the adsorption rate of a gas molecule upon a surface and its further reactivity on the surface [47], the over-predicted CO-cobalt binding energy led to underestimation of CO* conversion on the Co(0001) surface and affected all the subsequent reactions in the modeled FTS mechanism. Nevertheless, based on the pathways shown in Fig. 2 and Fig. 3, under both phase conditions, CO* oxygenation to carbon dioxide is a competitive undesired side-reaction against CO* (direct or associated) dissociation ending in hydrocarbon products. As it can be read from the rate values in these figures, the presence of liquid solvent not only lowered the relative rate of CO* oxygenation to CO2** by about 2 orders of magnitude, but also the overall CHEMKIN outcomes showed that under similar reaction conditions (temperature and pressure) and at the same reactant conversion, CO2 production rate in the presence of liquid solvent reduced by an order of magnitude compared to that of gaseous-phase, which is in agreement with experimental results [1]. Due to the enhanced dissolving of products in the liquid solvent, the absolute values of intrinsic reaction rates in the modeled mechanism were calculated to be greater in the liquid-phase compared to the gaseous-phase. However, in practical situations the diffusion barrier and transport resistances caused by the liquid-phase solvent (which was not considered in our model) not only neutralize the enhanced solvation effect, but also would reduce the overall rate of reactions in liquid-phase FTS. 4 Conclusion COSMO calculations were included in DFT modeling of the FTS process on Co(0001) catalyst in order to probe the effect of liquid solvent on the heterogeneous catalytic reactions. In addition to energy barriers, the rate constants of elementary reactions in the considered mechanism were calculated quantum mechanically, through the use of transition state theory. Comparing the liquid-phase results with those of gaseous-phase, it was found that the presence of liquid hexane solvent increased the formation rate and thermodynamic stability of larger oxygenate intermediates relative to the gas phase, which led to an additional reaction pathway toward more production of heavier hydrocarbons. While the current calculations show that the carbide mechanism is the dominant reaction pathway in the different types of FTS, the presence of the liquid solvent helped enhance the contribution of the CO insertion mechanism, beside the main pathway. In the modeled mechanism, the elementary reactions were considered up to C2 fraction products. However, we strongly believe that the enhanced chain growth discussed here likely extends similarly to hydrocarbon products with greater number of carbons, which is in agreement with experimental observations. Moreover, unlike the reactant’s diffusion and adsorption rates, due to presence of liquid solvent, the overall rate of adsorbed CO* dissociation on the surface was accelerated significantly, which reduced the undesired formation of CO2, compared to gaseous-phase FTS under similar operating conditions. While the calculated rates in the considered elementary mechanism under both phase conditions resulted exclusively in ethane and carbon dioxide production with only trace amounts of ethylene and methane, this work shows that implementing the COSMO continuum solvent model in first principle DFT calculations provides an acceptable model toward capturing the liquid solvent effects on the surface mechanism of the heterogeneous catalytic FTS process, one which is capable of describing some of the experimental observations. coredata.dc:description: The process of Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) is conducted commercially under both gaseous- and liquid-phase conditions. For decades, numerous studies have been performed to better understand this heterogeneous catalytic process, where some of them have tried to compare the reaction rates and product distributions of FTS under different phase conditions. In spite of several provided models, the actual reaction mechanisms and kinetics of important elementary steps at each phase condition are still under investigation, especially in the liquid-phase. In this work, we have utilized the generalized-gradient approximation method of density functional theory (DFT-GGA) to estimate the rate parameters of elementary reactions in liquid-phase FTS on a flat Co(0001) catalyst surface. In this regard, using the continuum-based conductor-like screening model (COSMO) for the liquid solvent environment, the activation energies and rate constants of individual reactions, suggested in an existing microkinetic model, have been calculated in the presence of n-hexane solvent at T =493K and P =25bar. The preferred reaction pathway has been discussed and the quantitative results have been compared to that of the gaseous-phase in order to find the impact of liquid solvent, as well as differences in the probable surface reactions under each phase condition. It has been found that while the carbide mechanism is the dominant mechanism of chain growth under both phase conditions, the presence of the liquid solvent enhanced the CO insertion sub-mechanism of chain growth, which can describe some of the experimental observations in FTS studies.
coredata.dc:title: A density functional theory based elementary reaction mechanism for early steps of Fischer-Tropsch synthesis over cobalt catalyst. 2. Microkinetic modeling of liquid-phase vs. gaseous-phase process
